title: Distributed Data Show Episode 10: Mastering Cassandra and DataStax Enterprise with Tanya Gallagher
description:
Tanya Gallagher explains why you need a learning path for Apache Cassandra and DataStax Enterprise and gives us an inside look at how the DataStax Curriculum Engineering team stays up to speed as they maintain content like our free online courses at DataStax Academy and live, instructor-led training.

ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 5
DataStax Enterprise 5.0, the database platform for cloud applications, includes Apache Cassandra 3.x with materialized views, tiered storage and advanced replication. Introduced in 5.0 is DataStax Enterprise Graph, the first graph database fast enough to power customer-facing applications, scale to massive datasets and integrate advanced tools to power deep analytical queries.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://academy.datastax.com/resources/whats-new-datastax-enterprise-50

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax 
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/datastax
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX ACADEMY
On the DataStax Academy YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax EnterpriseÂ©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

me this is really exciting a little intimidating with all the evangelists but it'll be fun alright so I've actually been in curriculum engineering for about 20 years I started out I got my master's degree in instructional design and it grew from there and during that time I was about half time I was a technical instructor as well because I do believe that if you actually teach your content in the classroom you really get a sense of how it's going and if you need to fix it and what works what doesn't work things like that so I was at one company for about 15 years and then about three years ago I came over to data stacks as a curriculum engineer and I moved up the ranks a bit to director of curriculum engineering and now I head up a team of of five awesome curriculum engineers Wow so I don't know why you're intimidated having a whole Cod array of highly opinionated engineers doesn't sound intimidating at all no not at all but not to make you feel worse but we do have questions too so right we're gonna do a round-robin on the questions yeah opinionated engineers have questions you have answers but I think these are good questions because these are gonna speak to a common problem you can also like this and there's also you can take on-site courses so if you want to take curriculum at your own customer site we do have either public courses which are taught publicly to anyone any company come and come to those and those are often taught on-site in Santa Clara or you can arrange to have an on-site course just for your company of any of our curriculum let's go back to DSA because that's a pretty cool thing you can first thing you need to have an account on DSA so if you don't have an account absolutely get one it's gonna open open a whole new world for you for Cassandra and data stacks Enterprise so you're gonna get to there you can get to DSA you'll navigate to our online courses once you navigate to our online courses we have all kinds of neat stuff out there to help you get familiar with Cassandra DSC and all parts of DSA Deus Ex Enterprise okay so we can go to Academy data stacks comm and specifically once we're looking at our long-form courses it so that it was somewhat obvious but if it isn't let me just point out a couple of things if you don't know anything about Cassandra the first thing I recommend is go look at DES 101 which is only a 30 minute introduction to Cassandra there's no exercises or anything it's just a cool overview of what Cassandra is as a great way to start and from there if you're ready you go over to DS 201 des 201 is is foundations of Apache Cassandra and if you do it under sects Academy it's about six hours of videos that you can watch with those videos we also have a virtual machine that can be downloaded from data stacks Academy to your own machine and then you could launch that machine and actually run through all our exercises you can also download all the course content so you can download the slides if you want to go through them yourself as well as the exercise file you'll need the exercise files say that you know what to do with the virtual machine at the end of the videos there's often a link as well that will bring you to some quiz questions and the quiz questions are just going to test your understanding of that particular video and so each course is made up of several videos and once you get through all of those you've completed a course when you're done with DES 201 if you're an administrator you'll probably pop into the das2 10 which is operations for Apache Cassandra and that'll that'll get you through some you know the typical operations performance tune and kind of stuff that you'll have to do if you are a developer you might jump straight to ds2 20 which is data something more advanced we have more advanced training available than what's just there on DSA yes absolutely so if you were on DSA you probably noticed that you could see the 200 level courses and 300 level courses and that was cool however we do have 400 level courses we have a DS 410 which is it man advanced administration for a Deus Ex enterprise and we also have a 420 which is at advanced setting you'll have to reach out to that either training at datus XCOM or go to data stacks are sorry Academy - XCOM and go look for the link for on-site courses ok so so I got a question here but so what going back to something you said a little bit earlier about about some of the courses and some of the content and everything like this is this kind of near and dear to me because when I first came to Davis tax I spent weeks in every one of the DSA courses like going through them all learning as much as I could and you actually mentioned the BMS so I'm gonna brown-nose here a little bit because honestly the amount of information and the amount of work that was clearly put into not only the course material itself but then the VMS with all the exercises was really quite awesome I mean it's some really comprehensive stuff so that's really neat so I guess now I'm done with my brother nosing my question - always like what is the secret sauce that makes that makes Davis X Academy like how do you guys put all the courses together you know get all that content that's a good question actually there's a lot that goes into it there's a lot that goes on in the background and I don't think people realize how much work it is to actually put together curriculum but to start with first thing we did is that we built something called the skills tree and the skills tree is all of the knowledge we think you need in order to be an expert in a particular topic so an example of a skills tree is we have a skill stray that's called Cassandra expert and what we did is we we wrote down every little piece of knowledge in a tree that builds you know there are nodes that build on other nodes that build on other nodes and we built this tree to give us a visual representation of all the kinds of things you'd have to learn and then from there we worked with experts within the community as well as within data stacks to figure out what kind of gaps there are knowledge gaps there are out in the out in the customer base or with anybody taking our curriculum so we would talk to the sport engineers and we'd say hey support engineers we're really curious what kinds of things do you see over and over again and how can we and curriculum help you not see those same questions over and over again an example might be compaction let's say everyone has trouble understanding compaction so supports getting inundated lots of questions about compaction and so we figure hey if we can help alleviate some of that load on support we're doing a good job so we make sure we add that to our curriculum we also work with a solution architects who go out there all the time there are there are sort of our Road Warriors are out there helping customers all the time we ask them hey guys what is it that you see in the field that could help your customers what could we do to improve our curriculum so that your customers have a better knowledge base when you come in and you guys are just helping them with their particular use case we also work with sales and say hey what do you guys want to see in terms of curriculum from there we write we write what's called a and our educational narrative and in that narrative we decide what is the best learning path or curriculum then we go and we write our our classes and the way we start is we all believe that the best way to learn anything is through hands-on or through exercises some people learn by just reading or listening but a great many people learn by doing so what we do is we start with the exercises and we say what does this person need to know right now to be successful with this piece for example compaction what do they need to know about compaction to be successful how am I going to illustrate that in an exercise how am I gonna get them to do it okay great once I write the exercise I put some requisite knowledge around it so I might build some slides not a lot you know I don't want to build lots of slides so I build some slides around that piece and then I have to build a learning platform so we have to have an environment in which you guys can that customers and you guys can actually test our exercises so that might be a virtual machine or it might be a cloud infrastructure that you can use to to test our to actually go through our exercises and then once we're done with all that we hand our curriculum over the wall to our delivery organization at data stacks for them to actually go out and teach to either on-site classes or to teach public classes and then we also hand them over to
